dataset.title: Mycorrhizae in an experimental urban landscaped site in central Arizona-Phoenix

abstract.para: The primary objective of this project is to study Mycorrhizal relationships at an experimental xeric urban landscaped site . One study quantified the local diversity and spatial patterns of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungal (AMF) species. AMF species at 25 points in a 9.2 x 9.2 m regular grid pattern were identified using trap cultures. A total of twelve species were detected, with seven species detected in one plot and eleven in the other. Sampling effort curves and jackknife estimates indicate that a limited number of species was still undetected. No single species was dominant at either plot, and a rank-frequency plot for the site revealed a log-normal species distribution. The number of AMF species was not correlated with proximity to plants. Despite the patchiness of plants in the plots, the number of species detected per point exhibited spatial structuring only at the smallest sampling scale in a single plot, and only a single species in each plot was non-randomly distributed.The results indicate that there is a diverse AMF propagule bank at the site and/or there has been significant in-migration from the surrounding metacommunity. The second study examined the effects of three shoot pruning techniques (shearing every 6 weeks, heading back every 6 months and renewal pruning every year) on root length density, biomass, AMF colonization and soil respiration in two woody shrubs, Nerium oleander (oleander) and Leucophyllum frutescens (Texas sage). Roots were sampled at the base of plants by soil coring to depths of 0-20 cm and 20-40 cm in February, after the shearing and heading back treatments had been imposed, but prior to the first renewal pruning, and in May, after all treatments had been imposed. Shearing stimulated root biomass in Nerium in February, but shearing and renewal pruning reduced biomass compared to unpruned plants in both species in May. Nerium colonization was stimulated by shearing and heading back in February and by shearing and renewal pruning in May. Root biomass, length, and soil respiration associated with Leucophyllum were reduced by all pruning treatments in May. The results indicate that heading back may be the most appropriate pruning practice for these shrubs in xeric landscaping.

listitem.para: While CAP LTER will make every effort possible to control and document the quality of the data it publishes, the data are made available "as is".
CAP LTER cannot assume responsibility for damages resulting from mis-use or mis-interpretation of datasets or from errors or omissions that may exist in the data.
It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists that has resulted in data used in subsequent research.
CAP LTER expects that any use of data from this server will be accompanied with the appropriate citations and acknowledgments.

CAP LTER encourages users to contact the original investigator responsible for the data that they are accessing. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on CAP LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
CAP LTER requests that users submit to the Global Institute of Sustainability, ASU, one copy of any publication resulting from the use of data obtained from this site.
CAP LTER requests that users not redistribute data obtained from this site. However, links or references to this site may be freely posted.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Phoenix metropolitan area in Arizona, USA

section.title: ASSESSING LOCAL DIVERSITY OF ARBUSCULAR MYCORRHIZAL FUNGAL SPECIES IN AN EXPERIMENTAL URBAN LANDSCAPED SITE
section.para: 1. Seven 9.2 × 9.2 m experimental plots were established in April 1999 at the site after vegetation was removed by discing.
2. The plants were propagated by stem cuttings and grown in containers in a mixture of native soil, bark, sand, TurfliteTM (Sierra Cascade, Chemult, OR) and slow release fertilizer.
3. Water is applied by drip irrigation at the base of each plant at an average rate of 2401 L per plant per year.
4. All woody plants were fertilized during April of each year with 200 g of controlled release 20N-4.4P-4K plus micronutrients fertilizer .

5. Winter and summer broadcast applications of pre-emergent herbicide (XL 2G, Dow Elanco Specialty Products, Indianapolis, IN) were made to each plot to inhibit weed seed germination. Plots were regularly weeded by hand thereafter.
6. Two plots at the site were sampled,the soil was removed with a sanitized hand shovel to a depth of 10 cm and stored in sealed plastic bags at 4ºC.

7. Trap cultures were established by mixing a 250-cm3 portion of each soil sample with 250 cm3 of a 1:1 mixture of autoclaved #12 and #20 silica sand and placing the mixture in a D40 Deepot™ that had been pre-treated with a 10% household bleach solution .
8. The pots were planted with 50-60 seeds of Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench, and the plants were grown in a greenhouse for four months, then the grass was clipped and the pots were re-seeded
9. After another four months of growth, the soil was air dried, removed from the pots and stored in sealed plastic bags at 4ºC until further processing. .
10. AMF spores were isolated from each trap culture using the sucrose density gradient centrifugation method .

11. A thoroughly mixed 100-cm3 soil subsample was removed from each trap culture. The soil was homogenized in a blender with water for 1 min, and the liquid was decanted into a 500-µm sieve stacked on a 45-µm sieve.
12. The top sieve was rinsed thoroughly and the organic matter from the bottom sieve was decanted into a beaker.
13. This material was then placed in a centrifuge tube loaded with a 20%/60% sucrose gradient. The tubes were spun in a swinging arm centrifuge at 1500 g for 5 min.
14. The supernatant was poured off into a fine sieve, rinsed with water and washed into a petri dish.
15. The supernatant was poured off into a fine sieve, rinsed with water and washed into a petri dish. The washing was examined using a stereo microscope

section.title: EFFECTS OF PRUNING ON ROOTS, MYCORRHIZAE, AND SOIL RESPIRATION OF TWO LANDSCAPE SHRUBS
section.para: 1. Seven experimental plots (9.2 m × 9.2 m) were established at the site in 1999 and each planted with 3.8 L container-grown clones of two common landscape shrubs
2. Water was applied at an average rate of 2401 L per shrub per year via drip emitters at the base of each shrub.
3. Three pruning treatments were performed in a completely randomized design; Shrubs in two of the plots were sheared; shrubs in two plots were headed back; shrubs in two plots were renewal pruned
4. Roots from the two shrub species were sampled in February and May to determine the effects of these treatments on root length density, root biomass and AMF colonization

5. The plots were sampled in February, just before the first renewal pruning and the second heading back treatment, and three weeks after a shearing treatment. They were sampled again in May, 15 wk after renewal pruning and heading back, and immediately after a shearing treatment.
6. The soil cores from each depth were stored separately in plastic bags on ice and transported to the laboratory, where they were kept at 4ºC until processing.

7. Wet weight of all live fine roots (less than 2 mm in diameter) was determined and a portion (ca. 0.1 g) of roots from each sample was removed and fixed in 70% ethanol for later quantification of root length and arbuscular mycorrhizal colonization.

8. The remaining roots were dried in an oven for at least 48 h and weighed. Total root biomass for the sample was determined by calculating the percentage of fresh roots removed for AMF colonization analysis and adding this percentage to the final dry weight of the remaining sample.
9. The AMF colonization subsample was cleared and stained according to a modification of the method of Koske and Gemma .

10. The fixed roots were rinsed in water and cleared in 5% potassium hydroxide at 90º C for 15 min. The roots were then rinsed thoroughly and bleached in alkaline hydrogen peroxide for 1 h to overnight, then acidified in 1% hydrochloric acid and stained in 0.05% trypan blue in acidic glycerol in an autoclave at 121º C for 3 min.
11. The stained roots were mounted on glass slides and scanned to determine percent colonization using the magnified intersections method of McGonigle et al. .

12. Each slide was scanned at 400 and a total of 100 root intersections were scored for percent colonization by AMF hyphae, arbuscules, vesicles, and hyphal coils. This percentage was multiplied by the RLD to determine the length of root colonized per cm3 of soil.

13. Soil CO2 efflux was measured at each sampling location to quantify the impact of the treatments on soil respiration rates. PVC collars (10 cm diameter × 10 cm length) were placed in the soil immediately adjacent to the root sampling locations at least one day prior to sampling.

14. CO2 efflux rates were measured with an LI-6200 portable photosynthesis system (LI-COR, Lincoln, NE) just prior to soil coring. Measurements were taken once every 30 s for 2 min and averaged for a 2 min mean.
